questions.question_text: Which statement is true about a pre-authenticated request in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Object Storage?

discussion.content: D is correct for $1 million

comments.content: Hello. I did two days ago and I've seen a lot of similar questions here (some are exactly the same). Some of the answers here are incorrect so pay attention to the discussion tab where people says the correct answers
Regards Sidney, do you present 1z0-1072 exam? The questions was similar to his dumps? Thanks in advance

discussion.content: D: https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Object/Tasks/usingpreauthenticatedrequests.htm

choices.A: You can create only 1, 000 pre-authenticated requests per bucket.
choices.B: You can create a pre-authenticated request only for public buckets.
choices.D: You cannot extend the expiration date on a pre-authenticated request.
choices.C: You cannot retire a pre-authenticated request before it expires.

choices.D: Data retrieval in Archive Object Storage is instantaneous.
choices.A: An Archive Object Storage tier bucket can be upgraded to the Standard Object Storage tier.
choices.C: An existing Standard Object Storage tier bucket can be downgraded to the Archive Object Storage tier.
choices.B: You cannot directly download an object from an Archive Object Storage bucket.

questions.question_text: Which statement is true about Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Object Storage Service?

discussion.content: B is correct. You gotta restore it first and then download.
B is correct

To Know why A, C and D are wrong, check this https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Archive/Concepts/archivestorageoverview.htm#Overview_of_Archive_Storage: 
-An existing Object Storage bucket cannot be downgraded to an Archive Storage bucket.
-An Archive Storage bucket cannot be upgraded to an Object Storage bucket.
and
-To download an object from Archive Storage, you must first restore the object. Restoration takes at most an hour from the time an Archive Storage restore request is made, to the time the first byte of data is retrieved

comments.content: Sorry i read the question wrong. B is correct.

discussion.content: D is right answer.
B is correct.
Ans: B

questions.question_text: For a compute instance that is launched in a private subnet in a Virtual Cloud Network (VCN), which action needs to be performed to connect to the Internet, assuming that the required security list is properly set up?

discussion.content: At first glance, D looks correct. But the question isnt asking about sending ALL traffic out to the internet. So D's incorrect, which leaves us with B only.

Answer is B 
Resources that need to use the gateway for internet access must be in a public subnet and have public IP addresses. Resources that have private IP addresses can instead use a NAT gateway to initiate connections to the internet.

Guys internet gateway cannot be attached to a private subnet.

NAT Gateway for sure, the only way to let traffig go outside a PRIVATE network.
B is correct as it talks about internet and no incoming traffic from internet.

Question is about connection from an compute in private VCN to internet. It is about one way traffic from compute to internet like a personal computer connecting to internet. NAT allows for such traffic so B is correct. Internet Gateway opens up both side of traffic (in and out bound to internet), hence incorrect.

Question is about connection from an compute in private VCN to internet. It is about one way traffic from compute to internet like a personal computer connecting to internet. NAT allows for such traffic so B is correct.

Regardless of default route, a device will require some form of public address to communicate over the internet, hence NAT. So instantly, B is the answer, I don't understand how this is confusing. Keywords here are "private subnet" and "internet" BINGO.

Answer is BBBBB.
Answer is D

B is completely wrong, it doesn't speak about "NAT gateway" but just "NAT", and anyway NAT GW is VCN level not subnet level as written.
D is for all traffic.
I think A, as each istance has at least one private ip_addr and i can attach public ip_addr

B

An internet gateway is an optional virtual router you can add to your VCN to enable direct connectivity to the internet.
The gateway supports connections initiated from within the VCN (egress) and connections initiated from the internet (ingress).
Resources that need to use the gateway for internet access must be in a public subnet and have public IP addresses. Resources that have private IP addresses can instead use a NAT gateway to initiate connections to the internet.
B is correct -- NAT, if internet gateway is needed why do you use Private Subnet.

comments.content: I will also go for D, look at use case of NAT gateway in oracle its for Databases that needs only to request infor like patches from the internet and there is no inbound traffic from the internet, but here the instance create need to communicate with the internet so thts probably inbound and outbound communication

discussion.content: NAT doesnâ€™t allow inbound traffic from a request from the internet. For me it should be option D based on the with Internet Gateway you can grant HTTP traffic to the instance hosted on the Private Subnet.
Key Info: Private Subnet.

choices.D: Create a default route entry in the route table to forward all traffic to the Internet gateway.
choices.B: Create and configure Network Address Translation (NAT) in a public subnet and route all traffic to it.
choices.A: Assign a Public IP address to the compute instance.
choices.C: There is no way for an instance in a private subnet to connect to the Internet.

questions.question_text: Which two are valid options when migrating a database from on-premises to Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI)? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Ths answer is B,C
For me the correct answers are BC. You can backup the DB to an OCI object storage and restore from that restore.
I believe it is B and C; Not A.
B and C are correct
Seems like B and C

comments.content:
In the link.... Normal Object Storage charges apply for the storage of your backup in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure.
Hence, BC

discussion.content: AC are correct. https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Database/Tasks/mig-onprembackup.htm

choices.C: performing RMAN backup to an on-premises storage device, and then shipping to OCI
choices.A: snapping or cloning storage form on-premises to OCI
choices.D: converting the Oracle database to a NoSQL database and migrating to OCI by using rsync file copy
choices.B: performing a backup to OCI object storage, and then restoring to a database server on OCI

choices.C: You need to log in to each region separately to create users for that particular region.
choices.A: You can assign a region to each of the users at the time of creation.
choices.B: Identity and Access Management (IAM) users are global and non-admin users can add resources to any region by default.
choices.D: IAM users are global. As an administrator, make sure that you subscribe to the Ashburn region.

questions.question_text:
You are responsible for setting up access for all the cloud users of a large enterprise. You log in to the Phoenix region and start creating users and policies. You then realize that some users might be creating resources in the Ashburn region.
Which step should you perform to enable those users?

discussion.content: D is correct. Admins need to have subscribed to all regions they need to administer. https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Identity/Tasks/managingregions.htm
D is correct.
D is correct.
